text: in the third year of his reign he gave a feast for all his officials and servants. The army of Persia and Media and the nobles and governors of the provinces were before him,
speaker: Narrator

text: while he showed the riches of his royal glory and the splendour and pomp of his greatness for many days, 180 days.

text: And when these days were completed, the king gave for all the people present in Susa, the citadel, both great and small, a feast lasting for seven days in the court of the garden of the king's palace.

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to the wise men who knew the times (for this was the king's procedure towards all who were versed in law and judgement,
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: “According to the law, what is to be done to Queen Vashti, because she has not performed the command of King Ahasuerus delivered by the eunuchs?”

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: So when the decree made by the king is proclaimed throughout all his kingdom, for it is vast, all women will give honour to their husbands, high and low alike.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This advice pleased the king and the princes, and the king did as Memucan proposed.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: And Haman said to the king, “For the man whom the king delights to honour,

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to Haman, “Hurry; take the robes and the horse, as you have said, and do so to Mordecai the Jew, who sits at the king's gate. Leave out nothing that you have mentioned.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Haman took the robes and the horse, and he dressed Mordecai and led him through the square of the city, proclaiming before him, “Thus shall it be done to the man whom the king delights to honour.”

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: So the king and Haman went in to feast with Queen Esther.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: as the days on which the Jews got relief from their enemies, and as the month that had been turned for them from sorrow into gladness and from mourning into a holiday; that they should make them days of feasting and gladness, days for sending gifts of food to one another and gifts to the poor.

text: So the Jews accepted what they had started to do, and what Mordecai had written to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Haman the Agagite, the son of Hammedatha, the enemy of all the Jews, had plotted against the Jews to destroy them, and had cast Pur (that is, cast lots), to crush and to destroy them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when it came before the king, he gave orders in writing that his evil plan which he had devised against the Jews should return on his own head, and that he and his sons should be hanged on the gallows.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore they called these days Purim, after the term Pur. Therefore, because of all that was written in this letter, and of what they had faced in this matter, and of what had happened to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Jews firmly bound themselves and their offspring and all who joined them, that without fail they would keep these two days according to what was written and at the time appointed every year,
speaker: Narrator

text: that these days should be remembered and kept throughout every generation, in every clan, province, and city, and that these days of Purim should never fall into disuse among the Jews, nor should the commemoration of these days cease among their descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Queen Esther, the daughter of Abihail, and Mordecai the Jew gave full written authority, confirming this second letter about Purim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Letters were sent to all the Jews, to the 127 provinces of the kingdom of Ahasuerus, in words of peace and truth,
speaker: Narrator

text: that these days of Purim should be observed at their appointed seasons, as Mordecai the Jew and Queen Esther bound them, and as they had bound themselves and their offspring, with regard to their fasts and their lamenting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The command of Queen Esther confirmed these practices of Purim, and it was recorded in writing.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Ahasuerus imposed tax on the land and on the coastlands of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the acts of his power and might, and the full account of the high honour of Mordecai, to which the king advanced him, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the kings of Media and Persia?
speaker: Narrator

text: For Mordecai the Jew was second in rank to King Ahasuerus, and he was great among the Jews and popular with the multitude of his brothers, for he sought the welfare of his people and spoke peace to all his people.
speaker: Narrator
